Debido a los esfuerzos de esta familia por obtener más territorio, se produjeron varios conflictos con los nobles vecinos (por ejemplo, el incendio de Nymburk en 1326) e incluso enfrentamientos con el ejército real de Wenceslao IV. Durante las Guerras Husitas, Frýdlant se convirtió en el centro de la oposición anti-husita, y el señorío de Frýdlant fue atacado varias veces entre 1420 y 1433. La ciudad de Frýdlant y otros pueblos de los alrededores fueron quemados en varias ocasiones. La casa Biberstein se mantuvo en oposición incluso contra el rey Jorge de Poděbrady y estuvo involucrada en otros conflictos militares. Durante el gobierno del último miembro de la familia Biberstein, el señorío de Frýdlant se convirtió completamente al protestantismo. El último descendiente varón, Cristóbal, murió en 1551 sin heredero, y así el castillo con todas las tierras señoriales pasó a la cámara real checa.

houses.title: Los Redern
houses.description: La casa de silesia, que contribuyó al crecimiento del protestantismo y la construcción del castillo.

owners.name: Federico de Redern
owners.label: Federico de Redern era miembro de una familia caballeresca de Silesia.
owners.text: Federico de Redern era miembro de la familia caballeresca de Silesia. Durante su vida, ocupó el cargo de presidente de la Cámara de Tierras de Silesia y fue miembro de la comisión real para registrar el estado del señorío de Frýdlant después de la muerte del último propietario. En 1558 fue Federico quien compró las propiedades de Liberec, Frýdlant y Zawidow en Bohemia del Norte. Después de comprarlos, alcanzó la elevación a la nobleza. Él y su esposa Salomena de Schönaich tuvieron un total de 10 hijos. Murió en 1564 durante su estancia en Wroclaw, Polonia.

owners.name: Melchor de Redern
owners.label: Fue el noveno de un total de diez hijos de Friedrich de Redern.
owners.text: Fue el noveno de un total de diez hijos de Federico de Redern. Estudió derecho en una universidad protestante en Heidelberg y luego, junto con su hermano Christopher, realizó un viaje de caballeros a Francia, donde en 1572 presenció el asesinato de los hugonotes durante la llamada Noche de Bartolomé. Además de Francia, también visitó las ciudades italianas de Roma, Padua o Nápoles. Melchor finalmente se unió al servicio en el ejército. En las décadas de 1570 y 1580 participó en el asedio de Gdańsk, la campaña anti húngara, la guerra de los Países Bajos o el asedio de Pskov. Después de la muerte de su hermano Christopher en 1591, se convirtió en propietario del señorío de Frýdlant. Se casó con Catalina de Šlik, pariente de uno de los nobles protestantes más influyentes, Joaquín Andreas de Šlik, que era el propietario de la finca vecina. Durante su vida se realizaron modificaciones constructivas en la zona del castillo. Agregó un ala al castillo, se creó el ala renacentista del palacio y, finalmente, también la capilla del castillo. En la década de 1590, Melchor regresó varias veces a los campos de batalla húngaros como oficial. A principios de la primavera de 1600 participó en una reunión en Viena sobre el próximo avance militar contra los turcos, sin embargo durante el otoño interrumpió su campaña militar por motivos de salud y falleció en septiembre de ese año.

owners.name: Catalina de Redern
owners.label: Catalina de Redern, nacida Šlik, era una pariente de Joaquín Andreas de Šlik, uno de los ejecutados en la Plaza de la Ciudad Vieja en 1621.
owners.text: Catalina de Redern, nacida Šlik, era una pariente de Joaquín Andreas de Šlik, uno de los ejecutados en la Plaza de la Ciudad Vieja en 1621. Entre 1600 y 1611, ella administró la finca de Frýdlant en nombre de su hijo menor de edad, Christopher. Su trabajo en la finca de Frýdlant está principalmente relacionado con disputas con los habitantes locales sobre el derecho a elaborar cerveza. Las malas relaciones con los habitantes locales eventualmente resultaron en que ella se quedara principalmente en el castillo de Liberec. Durante su mandato, se completaron las capillas del castillo en Frýdlant y Liberec, y se construyeron otras iglesias en todo el señorío de Frýdlant. Falleció en 1617 en Liberec, y se suponía que sería enterrada en la tumba familiar en Frýdlant, pero eso nunca sucedió y el lugar de su sepultura sigue siendo desconocido.

owners.name: Cristóbal de Redern
owners.label: Christopher se hizo cargo de la administración de la finca en 1611.
owners.text:
Cristóbal asumió la administración de la finca en 1611. Continuó la disputa con los habitantes del pueblo de Frýdlant, que había comenzado durante el reinado de su madre. Después del estallido del levantamiento de Bohemia, se unió a la unión protestante junto con su tío Joaquín Andreas de Šlik, y se convirtió en el comandante de una división de caballería. En ese momento, ya estaba experimentando problemas de salud.

Después de la derrota en 1620, su señorío fue confiscado y se exilió en la finca Zawidow. En 1627, también le confiscaron la propiedad de Zawidow. Luego se estableció en la residencia de su esposa, Magdalena de Hundt, en Polonia. Durante la incursión de los suecos en Bohemia entre 1639 y 1640, regresó a Frýdlant, pero ese mismo año tuvo que abandonar la mansión de Frýdlant. Falleció en el exilio en algún momento después de 1641.

houses.title: La casa de silesia, que contribuyó al crecimiento del protestantismo y la construcción del castillo.
houses.description: Albrecht de Wallenstein fue un líder militar checo, político y una de las figuras más importantes de la historia checa.

owners.name: Alberto de Wallenstein
owners.label: Albrecht de Wallenstein nació en una familia protestante no muy rica e influyente y eventualmente se convirtió en uno de los hombres más poderosos de importancia europea.
owners.text:
Albrecht de Wallenstein nació en una familia protestante no muy rica e influyente y eventualmente se convirtió en uno de los hombres más poderosos de importancia europea. Su mandato en Frýdlant no fue largo, duró solo 12 años, aun así, este es el tiempo que hizo que este lugar y la mansión fueran los más famosos e incluso se elevó a un ducado.

 La vida de Alberto de Wallenstein estuvo ligada al servicio en el ejército desde muy joven. Pronto desertó del campo protestante al servicio imperial y en los campos de batalla de la Guerra de los Treinta Años alcanzó el rango más alto en el mando militar, es decir, Generalísimo del Ejército Imperial. Sus posesiones, que incluían la mansión de Frýdlant, se salvaron más o menos de los principales conflictos bélicos y por eso se las denominó 'la tierra feliz - terra felix'. En cuanto a la mansión Frýdlant, durante el reinado de Wallenstein, podemos hablar de un auge económico, principalmente en industrias que estaban asociadas con las necesidades de la época: minería y procesamiento de metales o producción de pólvora. El castillo y el castillo estaban deshabitados y solo se realizaron modificaciones estructurales menores. Wallenstein permaneció aquí solo unos días en 1627, 1628 y 1630. El final de la vida de Wallenstein fue anunciado por la pérdida de confianza del emperador, quien se sintió amenazado por Wallenstein, razón por la cual Wallenstein fue asesinado por sus oficiales a principios de 1634.

houses.title: Gallas
houses.description: Casa del norte de Italia que contribuyó a la expansión de la mansión señorial de Frýdlant para incluir el castillo de Lemberk y sus alrededores.

owners.name: Matías de Gallas
owners.label: La vida de Matías de Gallas y su ascenso social estuvieron, como en el caso de Wallenstein, estrechamente relacionados con el período de la Guerra de los Treinta Años.
owners.text: La vida de Matías de Gallas y su ascenso social estuvieron, al igual que en el caso de Wallenstein, estrechamente relacionados con el período de la Guerra de los Treinta Años. Matías se unió al ejército cuando era joven y se hizo famoso por primera vez en las guerras de sucesión de Mantua, del lado de la Liga Católica. En 1628 entró al servicio de Alberto de Wallenstein y se convirtió en uno de sus generales. En 1632 alcanzó el rango de conde. Después de la traición de Wallenstein, se convirtió en el heredero de la mansión de Frýdlant y más tarde en el comandante-jefe del ejército imperial, donde trabajó hasta el final de la Guerra de los Treinta Años. Para Frýdlant, su reinado significó el período entre 1640 y 1649, cuando el castillo y la ciudad fueron ocupados por las fuerzas suecas. Matías murió en Viena en 1647.

owners.name: Antonio de Gallas
owners.label: Antonio es el más joven de los hijos de Matías de Gallas.
owners.text: Antonio es el más joven de los hijos de Matías de Gallas. Perdió a su padre a la edad de 9 años. Después de estudios y un viaje caballeresco por Francia y Benelux, junto con su hermano Francisco Fernando, se hizo cargo de la administración de los feudos heredados. Durante su vida, trabajó como chambelán al servicio del Elector de Baviera y heredó de su padre el mando de regimientos militares. Su situación económica empeoró hasta el punto de que se vio obligado a vender su parte de señoríos y también a renunciar a los regimientos militares. Al final, se endeudó y vivió en Kladsko en las propiedades de su hijo Felipe Francisco.

owners.name: Francisco Fernando de Gallas
owners.label: Francisco es el mayor de los hijos de Matías de Gallas.
owners.text: Francisco es el mayor de los hijos de Matías de Gallas. Tras finalizar sus estudios y su periplo caballeresco, se hizo cargo de la administración de los señoríos heredados. El único título de corte que recibió fue el de chambelán de corte titular. Durante su vida permaneció principalmente en sus mansiones en Bohemia, principalmente en Praga y en el castillo de Horineves. Su vida en Frýdlant está relacionada principalmente con la rebelión de los súbditos liderada por el herrero Andreas Stelzig, que fue reprimida en 1680. Murió en 1697 y sus restos se conservan en la tumba ancestral de Hejnice.

owners.name: Juan Wenceslao de Gallas
owners.label: El miembro más importante de esta familia junto con Matías de Gallas.
owners.text: El miembro más importante de esta familia junto con Matías de Gallas. Trabajó al servicio de los emperadores José I y Carlos VI como chambelán imperial, un verdadero consejero privado y diplomático. Trabajó en el servicio diplomático en Londres, La Haya y Roma. Finalmente, fue nombrado virrey en Nápoles, donde murió en 1719. Es el fundador del posterior Palacio Clam-Gallas en el casco antiguo de Praga.

owners.name: Felipe José de Gallas
owners.label: El último miembro de la familia Gallas, gracias a la cual la finca Frýdlant se amplió para incluir el área alrededor de Lemberk.
owners.text:
El último miembro de la casa Gallas, gracias a la cual la finca Frýdlant se amplió para incluir el área alrededor de Lemberk. Durante su vida ocupó los cargos oficiales del más alto ayo regional del Reino de Bohemia y el juez del tribunal supremo. Después de que el ejército de los Habsburgo sufriera una derrota ante los prusianos en la Batalla de Liberec, la región de Frýdlant fue saqueada por los prusianos.

Murió en 1757 sin un heredero varón, la finca fue entonces administrada por su esposa Marie Anna. Después de su muerte, la propiedad pasó a su sobrino Cristián Felipe de Clam. La condición para eso fue la fusión de los escudos de armas y la adición del nombre Gallas. Eso dio origen a la casa Clam-Gallas.

houses.title: Clam-Gallas
houses.description: La casa Clam-Gallas vive en el castillo de Frýdlant. Durante su mandato, se llevó a cabo una importante reconstrucción del ala renacentista del castillo y la construcción de nuevas alas.

owners.name: Cristián Felipe de Clam-Gallas
owners.label: El primero de la línea Clam-Gallas, que también ocupó cargos en la corte de los Habsburgo durante su vida.
owners.text:
El primero de la línea Clam-Gallas, que también ocupó cargos en la corte de los Habsburgo durante su vida. Se convirtió en chambelán real de tres emperadores y fue ascendido a caballero de la orden de San Esteban. Amplió los latifundios familiares con otro territorio.

Fue un gran amante y mecenas de las artes. En su residencia de Praga acogió, por ejemplo, a Mozart o Beethoven. En la región de Frýdlant, se le asocia principalmente con la fundación de la ciudad balneario de Libverda, en Praga luego con la finca Klamovka.

owners.name: Cristián Cristóbal de Clam-Gallas
owners.label: Cristián Cristóbal de Clam-Gallas continuó el legado de su padre en términos de carrera y patrocinio.
owners.text:
Cristián Cristóbal de Clam-Gallas continuó el legado de su padre en términos de carrera y patrocinio. Tenía el rango de Mariscal Supremo del Reino Checo. Se casó con Josefina Carolina Clary-Aldringen, también gran amante del arte. Juntos mantuvieron contacto con, por ejemplo, Ludwig van Beethoven.

Contribuyó a una mayor actividad de construcción en Libverda, donde se construyeron nuevos pabellones de spa. Alrededor de Klamovka, estableció jardines con decoración escultórica.

owners.name: Guillermo de Clam-Gallas
owners.label: Guillermo de Clam-Gallas
owners.text: El mayor de los hijos de Cristián Cristóbal. Murió muy joven a la edad de 21 años. Está enterrado en la tumba ancestral en Hejnice.

owners.name: Eduardo de Clam-Gallas
owners.label: Eduardo era el más joven de los hijos de Cristiano Cristóbal y también el miembro más destacado de la familia Clam-Gallas.
owners.text:
Eduardo era el más joven de los hijos de Cristiano Cristóbal y también el miembro más destacado de la familia Clam-Gallas. En 1823 ingresó de joven al ejército, donde alcanzó el grado de general. Luchó bajo el mando del mariscal Radetykz en el norte de Italia durante la Primera Guerra de Independencia italiana, luego luchó en Hungría y regresó a la Segunda Guerra en el norte de Italia. Las batallas más significativas en las que participó son las batallas de Magenta y Solferino.

Durante la Guerra Prusiano-Austríaca, sufrió una derrota en la Batalla de Jičín, por lo que fue juzgado por un consejo de guerra. Aunque fue absuelto, nunca volvió al ejército y vivió el resto de su vida en Frýdlant y Liberec.

Durante su estadía en Frýdlant, hizo que el castillo local se sometiera a una extensa reconstrucción y modificaciones, durante las cuales se creó el ala más nueva del castillo. Murió en 1891 a la edad de 86 años.

owners.name: Francisco de Clam-Gallas
owners.label: El último descendiente masculino de la familia Clam-Gallas.
owners.text:
El último descendiente masculino de la familia Clam-Gallas también continuó su carrera en el servicio civil, siendo chambelán y consejero privado, pero sobre todo se dedicó a la gestión de las propiedades familiares Liberec, Frýdlant, Grabštejn y Lemberk.

La Primera Guerra Mundial y la creación de la República Checoslovaca, así como la reforma agraria intervinieron en su vida. Además de la agricultura, también dedicó toda su vida al trabajo voluntario y la caridad contribuyendo activamente a ello.

Murió en Frýdlant en 1930 y dejó 7 hijas. La segunda más joven de ellas, Clotilde, vivió en Frýdlant hasta el final de la Segunda Guerra Mundial.

owners.name: Clotilde de Clam-Gallas
owners.label: Clotilde de Clam-Gallas era la segunda hija menor de Francis Clam-Gallas y Maria Hoyos-Sprinzenstein.
owners.text: Clotilde de Clam-Gallas era la segunda hija menor de Francis Clam-Gallas y María Hoyos-Sprinzenstein. Durante la vida de Francisco, sus propiedades se dividieron entre sus hijas. Clotilde recibió entonces el castillo de Frýdlant. Permaneció soltera y después de la muerte de su padre, se hizo cargo de su madre viuda. Después de 1945, tuvo que mudarse al extranjero y el castillo fue nacionalizado.

history.title: Przegląd historii
history.card_label: Get to know the history of the Frýdlant castle and chateau.
history.description:
Frýdlant is one of largest and most important heritage sites in Northern Bohemia. It consists of two architectural complexes: a medieval castle and a renaissance chateau. The castle was built around the mid-13th century. In 1278, the domain became property of the Biberstein house who took major part in building the large castle palace. Between 1558 and 1620, Frýdlant was owned by the Redern house that continued to upgrade the domain. The Rederns were good managers and warriors, but also builders and art supporters. They built the new renaissance chateau and the chapel. 

Between 1622 and 1634, the castle belonged to Albrecht of Wallenstein. He bought it for 150,000 guldens and gradually built a large domain. His estates flourished greatly during the Thirty Years War as they supplied his army. The Frýdlant region was called Terra felix – the happy country. 

After Albrecht’s murder in 1634, the emperor gave Frýdlant to the Gallas house, and since 1759 the domain was owned by the Clam-Gallases, an important aristocratic house active in diplomatic and military circles at the imperial court. They remained until 1945 when Frýdlant became property of the state. 

The original gothic castle hasn’t been preserved in its entirety. Nowadays, the castle is a large two-floor building around the small, irregularly shaped courtyard, with the predominant cylindrical tower – a bergfrit. The castle was growing over time, and underwent two renaissance reconstructions in the 16th century. The chapel and the renaissance chateau were built at the turn of the 16th and 17th century by Marco Spazzio di Lancio. The last big reconstruction took place in the 1860s, when the castle warden wing was rebuilt. 

In 1801, the Clam-Gallases enabled public access to a part of the castle with exhibitions, making it the first castle museum in the Central Europe. The current exhibition includes this museum, the chapel with valuable items, and two chateau wings.
history.label: History of castle Frýdlant

houses.title: Ronowitzer
houses.description: Founders of Frýdlant Castle.

owners.name: Ronowitzer
owners.label: The oldest history of the Frýdlant castle is connected with the Ronowitzer family, who had it built in the 13th century.
owners.text: The oldest history of the Frýdlant castle is connected with the Ronowitzer family, who had it built in the 13th century. We don't know much about their activities in the northern part of Bohemia. The first known member of this family was Smil, who was a member of the retinue of King Přemysl Otakar I. His sons Henry and Častolov still use the epithet 'of Zittau' in 1238, but in 1257 we already find a mention of 'Častolov of Frýdlant'. The expansion of this family was limited in 1278 by King Přemysl Otakar II., when he took the estate from the Ronowitzer family and sold it to the Biberstein family.

houses.title: Biberstein
houses.description: The longest ruling house, which was responsible for the expansion of the castle.

owners.name: Biberstein
owners.label: Representatives of the Biberstein family became the owners of the Frýdlant castle for the next almost 300 years, and their reign is mainly connected with the construction expansion of the castle and the further growth of Frýdlant manor.
owners.text:
Representatives of the Biberstein family became the owners of the Frýdlant castle for the next almost 300 years, and their reign is mainly connected with the construction expansion of the castle and the further growth of Frýdlant manor. Due to this family's efforts for further territorial gains, there have been several conflicts with neighboring ones nobles (e.g. the burning of Nymburk in 1326) and even clash with the royal army of Wenceslaus IV. 

During the Hussite Wars, Frýdlant became the center of the anti-Hussite opposition, and the Frýdlant manor was attacked several times between 1420 and 1433. The town of Frýdlant and other villages in the vicinity were several times burned out. The Biberstein family then remained in opposition even against King Charles of Poděbrady and were involved in other military conflicts. During the rule of the last Biberstein, the Frýdlant manor became completely Protestant, which was followed by family of Redern. The last male descendant, Christoph, died in 1551 without an heir and thus the manor fell to the Czech royal chamber.

houses.title: Redern
houses.description: The Silesian house, which contributed to the growth of Protestantism and the construction of the chateau.

owners.name: Friedrich of Redern
owners.label: Friedrich of Redern was a member of the Silesian knightly family.
owners.text: Friedrich of Redern was a member of the Silesian knightly family. During his lifetime, he held the position of president of the Silesian Land Chamber and was a member of the royal commission to record the state of the Frýdlant manor after death of the last owner. In 1558 it was Friedrich, who bought the North Bohemian estates of Liberec, Frýdlant and Zawidow. After buying them, he reached elevation to nobility. He and his wife Salomena of Schönaich had a total of 10 children. He died in 1564 while staying in Wroclaw, Poland.

owners.name: Melchior of Redern
owners.label: He was the ninth of a total of ten children of Friedrich of Redern.
owners.text:
He was the ninth of a total of ten children of Friedrich of Redern. He studied law at a protestant university in Heidelberg and then together with his brother Christopher went on a cavalier trip to France, where in 1572 he witnessed the murder of the Huguenots during the so-called Bartholomew's Night. In addition to France, he also visited the Italian cities of Rome, Padua or Naples. Melchior eventually joined the service in the army. In the 1570s and 1580s, he took part in the siege of Gdańsk, the anti-Hungarian campaign, the war in the Netherlands or the Siege of Pskov. 

After death of his brother Christopher in 1591 he became the owner of the Frýdlant manor. He married Catherine of Šlik, the sister of one of the most influential Protestant noblemen, Jáchym Ondřej of Šlik, who was the owner of the neighboring estate. During his lifetime, construction modifications were made in the castle area. He added one castle wing, the of the castle, the Renaissance wing of thechateau was created, and eventually also the chateau chapel. In the 1590s, Melchior returned to the Hungarian battlefields several times as an officer. As early as the spring of 1600, he participated in a meeting in Vienna about the next military advance against the Turks, during the autumn however, he interrupts his military campaign due to health reasons and died in September of this year.

owners.name: Catherine of Redern
owners.label: Catherine of Redern, born Šlik, was the sister of Jáchym Ondřej of Šlik, one of those executed at Old Town Square in 1621.
owners.text:
Catherine of Redern, born Šlik, was the sister of Jáchym Ondřej of Šlik, one of those executed at Old Town Square in 1621. Between 1600 and 1611 she managed the Frýdlant manor for her underaged son Christopher. Her work on the Frýdlant estate is mainly connected with disputes with the local townspeople regarding the right to brew beer. Bad relations with the locals eventually resulted in her staying primarily at castle in Liberec. 

During her tenure, the chateau chapels in Frýdlant and Liberec were completed, and other churches were built in the entire Frýdlant manor. She died in 1617 in Liberec, she was to be buried in the family tomb in Frýdlant, but that never happened and the place of burial is still unknown.

owners.name: Christopher of Redern
owners.label: Christopher took over the administration of the estate in 1611.
owners.text:
Christopher took over the administration of the estate in 1611. He continued the dispute with the townspeople of Frýdlant, which began during his mother's reign. After the outbreak of Bohemian uprising, together with his uncle Jáchym Ondřej of Šlik, he was involved on the side of Protestant union where he became the commander of a cavalry division. He was already suffering from health problems at this time. 

After defeat in 1620, his manor was confiscated and he lived in exile on the Zawidow estate. In 1627, the Zawidow estate was also confiscated from him. He then lived in the residence of his wife Magdalena of Hundt in Poland. During the raid Swedes to Bohemia between 1639-1640, he returned to Frýdlant, but in the same year he had to leave Frýdlant manor to Wallenstein. He dies in exile sometime after 1641.

houses.title: Albrecht of Wallenstein
houses.description: Albrecht of Wallenstein was a Czech military leader, politician and one of the most important figures in the Czech history.

owners.name: Albrecht von Wallenstein
owners.label: Albrecht of Wallenstein was born into a not very wealthy and influential Protestant family and eventually became one of the most powerful men of European importance.
owners.text:
Albrecht of Wallenstein was born into a not very wealthy and influential Protestant family and eventually became one of the most powerful men of European importance. His tenure at Frýdlant was not long, it lasted only 12 years, even so, this is the time that made this place and the manor the most famous and it was even raised to a dukedom.

 The life of Albrecht of Wallenstein was connected with service in the army from a young age. He soon defected from the Protestant camp to the imperial service and on the battlefields of the Thirty Years' War he attained the highest rank in military command, i.e. Generalissimo of the Imperial Army. His possessions, which included the manor of Frýdlant were then more or less spared from major war conflicts and that is why they were referred to as 'the happy land - terra felix'.

 As for the Frýdlant manor, during Wallenstein's reign, we can talk about an economic rise, primarily in industries that were associated with the needs of the time – mining and metal processing or gunpowder production. The castle and chateau were uninhabited and only minor structural modifications took place. Wallenstein stayed here only for a few days in 1627, 1628 and 1630. The end of Wallenstein's life was heralded by the loss of trust from the emperor, who felt threatened by Walstein, which is why Wallenstein was murdered by his officers at the beginning of 1634.

houses.title: Gallas
houses.description: House from northern Italy, which contributed to the expansion of the Frýdlant manor to include Lemberk Castle and its surroundings.

owners.name: Matthias of Gallas
owners.label: The life of Matthias of Gallas and his social rise were, as in the case of Wallenstein, tightly connected with the period of the Thirty Years' War.
owners.text: The life of Matthias of Gallas and his social rise were, as in the case of Wallenstein, tightly connected with the period of the Thirty Years' War. Matthias joined the army as a young man and became famous for the first time in the wars for the Mantuan inheritance on the side of the Catholic League. In 1628 he entered the service of Albrecht of Wallenstein and became one of his generals. In 1632 he attained the rank of earl. After the betrayal of Wallenstein, he became the heir to the Frydlant manor and later the commander-in-chief of the Imperial army, where he worked until the end of the Thirty Years' War. For Frýdlant, his reign meant the period between 1640-1649 when the castle and town were occupied by Swedish crew. Matthias died in Vienna in 1647.

owners.name: Antonius of Gallas
owners.label: Antonius is the younger of the sons of Matthias of Gallas.
owners.text: Antonius is the younger of the sons of Matthias of Gallas. He lost his father at the age of 9. After studies and a cavalier journey after France and Benelux, together with his brother Francis Ferdinand, he took over the administration of inherited manors. During his lifetime, he worked as a chamberlain in the service of the Elector of Bavaria and inherited from his father the command of military regiments. His economic situation worsened to the point that he was forced to sell his share to manor and to gave up military regiments as well. In the end, he fell into debt and lived in Kladsk on estates of his son Philip Francis.

owners.name: Francis Ferdinand of Gallas
owners.label: Francis is the elder of the sons of Matthias of Gallas.
owners.text: Francis is the elder of the sons of Matthias of Gallas. After completing his studies and cavalier journey, he took over the administration of the inherited manors. The only court title he received was the titular court chamberlain. During his life he stayed mainly on his manors in Bohemia, mostly in Prague and at the castle in Hoříněves. His life in Frýdlant is mainly connected with the rebellion of the subjects led by the blacksmith Ondřej of Stelzig, which was suppressed in 1680. He died in 1697 and his remains are kept in the ancestral tomb in Hejnice.

owners.name: John Wenceslaus of Gallas
owners.label: The most important member of this family together with Matthias of Gallas.
owners.text: The most important member of this family together with Matthias of Gallas. He worked in the service of emperors Joseph I. and Charles VI. as an imperial chamberlain, a true privy councilor and diplomat. He worked in the diplomatic service in London, The Hague and Rome. He was eventually appointed viceroy in Naples, where he died in 1719. He is the founder of the later Clam-Gallas Palace in Prague's Old Town.

owners.name: Philip Joseph of Gallas
owners.label: The last member of the Gallas family, thanks to whom the Frýdlant estate was expanded to include the area around Lemberk.
owners.text:
The last member of the Gallas family, thanks to whom the Frýdlant estate was expanded to include the area around Lemberk. During his life he held the official positions of the highest regional hofmeister of the Kingdom of Bohemia and the highest court judge. After the Habsburg army suffered a defeat by the Prussians in the Battle of Liberec, the Frýdlant region was plundered by the Prussians. 

He died in 1757 without a male heir, the estate was then managed by his wife Marie Anna. After her death the estate was passed to his nephew Christian Philip of Clam. The condition for this was the merging coats of arms and the addition of the name Gallas. This gave rise to the house Clam-Gallas.

houses.title: Clam-Gallas
houses.description: The last family living in the Frýdlant castle. During her tenure, a major reconstruction of the Renaissance wing of the chateau and the construction of a new wing took place.

owners.name: Christian Philip of Clam-Gallas
owners.label: The first of the Clam-Gallas line, who also held offices at the Habsburg court during his lifetime.
owners.text:
The first of the Clam-Gallas line, who also held offices at the Habsburg court during his lifetime. He became royal chamberlain of three emperors and was promoted to knight of the order of St. Stephen. He expanded the family estates by another territory. 

He was a great lover and patron of the arts. In his Prague residence he hosted, for example, Mozart or Beethoven. In the Frýdlant region, he is primarily associated with the founding of the spa town of Libverda, in Prague then with the Klamovka estate.

owners.name: Christian Christopher of Clam-Gallas
owners.label: Christian Christopher of Clam-Gallas continued his father's legacy in terms of career and patronage.
owners.text:
Christian Christopher of Clam-Gallas continued his father's legacy in terms of career and patronage. He had the rank of Supreme Marshal of the Czech Kingdom. He married Josefina Caroline Clary-Aldringen, also a great lover of art. Together they maintained contact with, for example, Ludwig van Beethoven. 

He contributed to further construction activity in Libverda, where new spa pavilions were built. Around Klamovka,he established gardens with sculptural decoration.

owners.name: William of Clam-Gallas
owners.label: The elder of Christian Christopher's sons.
owners.text: The elder of Christian Christopher's sons. He died very young at the age of 21. He is buried in the ancestral tomb in Hejnice.

owners.name: Edward of Clam-Gallas
owners.label: Edward was the younger of Christian Christopher's sons and also the most prominent member of the Clam-Gallas family.
owners.text:
Edward was the younger of Christian Christopher's sons and also the most prominent member of the Clam-Gallas family. In 1823 he entered the army as a young man, where he reached the rank of general. He fought under the command of Marshal Radecký in Northern Italy during the First Italian War of Independence, then fought in Hungary and returned to the Second War in Northern Italy. The most significant of the battles in which he participated are the battles of Magenta and Solferin. 

During the Prussian-Austrian War, he suffered a defeat at the Battle of Jičín, for which he was judged by a court-martial. Even though he was acquitted, he never returned to the army and lived out his life in Frýdlant and Liberec. 

During his stay in Frýdlant, he had the local chateau undergo extensive reconstruction and building modifications, during which the newest wing of the chateau was created. He died in 1891 at the age of 86.

owners.name: Francis of Clam-Gallas
owners.label: The last male descendant of the Clam-Gallas family.
owners.text:
The last male descendant of the Clam-Gallas family. He too continued his civil service career, was chamberlain and privy councilor, but above all he devoted himself to the management of the family estates Liberec, Frýdlant, Grabštejn and Lemberk. 

The First World War, the creation of the Czechoslovak Republic and also the land reform intervened in his life. In addition to farming, he also devoted his whole life to volunteer work and charity, to which he actively contributed. 

He died in Frýdlanta in 1930 and left behind 7 daughters. The youngest of them, Clotilde, lived in Frýdlant until the end of World War II.

owners.name: Clotilde of Clam-Gallas
owners.label: Clotilde of Clam-Gallas was the youngest daughter of Francis Clam-Gallas and Maria Hoyos-Sprinzenstein.
owners.text: Clotilde of Clam-Gallas was the youngest daughter of Francis Clam-Gallas and Maria Hoyos-Sprinzenstein. During Francis' lifetime, his properties were divided between his daughters. Clotilde then received the Frýdlant Castle. She remained single after her father's death, she took care of her widowed mother. After 1945, she had to move abroad and the castle was nationalized.

tours.title: Castle
tours.description: This tour takes the visitor through the Upper Castle, which is the oldest part of the Frýdlant area. The entire route is dominated by a large knight's hall with an ancestral gallery, armory, banquet hall or a large collection of employee uniforms.

rooms.title: The chateau’s courtyard and lower terrace
rooms.card_label: Our tour begins at the chateau’s courtyard.
rooms.text:
Dear visitors, we welcome you to the state castle and chateau of Frýdlant. Before the start of the tour, we ask you to silence your mobile phones so that the tour is not disturbed. If you are using an audio guide, wear headphones while listening. Furthermore, we ask you not to touch the displayed exhibits and stay with your group. Thank you for your understanding and we wish you a pleasant visit.

Our tour begins at the chateau’s courtyard. Before we start climbing up to the castle, let’s take a look around the whole complex, which belongs amongst the largest and best preserved heritage sites in Bohemia.

The eldest part of Frýdlant towers on the rocky peak. The castle was founded in the first half of the 13th century, originally as a simple, gothic style fortress. Its current form is obviously much younger, broadly renaissance, and it was reached through numerous extensions and remodellings. To the left we find the chateau chapel. It was built in the late 16th and early 17th century together with the older chateau wing. The chateau’s facades are covered with sgraffito, a quintessential decoration of renaissance era palaces. The yellow branch of the chateau is the youngest part of the scene and it’s commonly called “the castellan's wing” as it houses the castle management’s offices ever since it was completed in 1869. The neo-renaissance style, fashionable at the time of construction, blends in with all the older buildings.

There are two access routes to the castle. The path winding along the fortification had for centuries been the only way up. Men would ride up on horseback, hence the nickname “knight’s path”. Ladies would be carried in a palanquin (a cart carried by 2 or 4 men). Later, in the 19th century, a staircase was added.

rooms.title: Under the covered bridge
rooms.card_label: The castle’s mediaeval core was founded on a basalt mass, which served as sort of an extra fortification.
rooms.text:
The castle’s mediaeval core was founded on a basalt mass, which served as sort of an extra fortification. The rock was named Devil’s Organs – based on its peculiar look and as well as a tale about a demon scratching the surface with his claws.

Above us there’s an enclosed bridge connecting the castle interiors with the chapel’s oratory.

We’re entering the castle now and as we will climb the stairs to another courtyard, you can take a look at three historical fire engines (forerunners of fire extinguishers) from the 18th and 19th century.

rooms.title: Castle courtyard
rooms.card_label: The castle courtyard, also called the small courtyard, is indeed surprisingly modest as to a castle of this size.
rooms.text:
The castle courtyard, also called the small courtyard, is indeed surprisingly modest as to a castle of this size. The fortress, however, was built on the very peak of a rock, leaving quite cramped space for a castle and the whole edifice could therefore expand solely upwards.

Much older than Frýdlant castle itself are the foundations of its tower Indika, which was built at the place of a 10th or 11th century watchtower. In this mediaeval period, Jizera mountains were sparsely (if even) populated and a watchtower provided safety and guidance to travellers on a trade route connecting Bohemia with Lusatia and Poland. The name Indika comes from the Latin verb “indicō”, meaning “to indicate” or “to point”, and it’s said there used to be a fire lit on top of the tower every night (though there’s no real evidence for it).

Starting in the middle of the 13th century the fortress was gradually built. In 1551, as this stone plaque reminds us, the whole castle was rebuilt in the renaissance style for the firsttime thanks to Bieberstein family, and several other renaissance renovations followed in the next 200 years, mainly when the castle was owned by Rederns. Once again we can see sgraffito, in this case rather elaborate with vivid depictions of St. Bartholomew's Day massacre and other events. On the opposite wall there’s a coat of arms of a more recent owner, Mathias von Gallas, accompanied by an account of his merits. We’ll talk a bit more about all the names and stories of Frýdlant’s nobility later, in the interiors.

Please remember not to use flash when taking pictures and do not touch any of the exhibits, including furniture.

rooms.title: Middle ages and early modern era
rooms.card_label: Let’s get to know the earliest history of this castle.
rooms.text:
Let’s get to know the earliest history of this castle. Although it’s acknowledged that the first border fortress was founded here before the middle of the 13th century, we have no record of an exact date nor a name of the initiator. Historically, it was believed that the first owners and probable founders came from the Ronovic family, however this scenario is considered more or less debunked today.

The eldest surviving written mention of Frýdlant castle is dated 1278 and it states that the property was entrusted to the care of Biebersteins by the king of Bohemia. The Bieberstein family became famous as military opponents of Hussites, a proto-Protestant movement. Of all owners they held Frýdlant for the longest period, nearly 300 years, during which time they had greatly expanded the castle and, as we have already seen carved into a stone, in 1551 they finished the first major renaissance style reconstruction. Nonetheless, in the very same year the last male heir died childless and the Bohemian Royal Chamber took over the property. We can see both coats of arms next to each other – the golden one with an antler belongs to the Bieberstein family, the red one with a double-tailed lion is the emblem of Bohemia, still used to this day.

The Bohemian Royal Chamber managed the domain until 1558, when Bedřich (/Friedrich) von Redern bought it. Following his death six years later, his sons took control and the youngest of them, Melchior, later became the only owner. He’s also the first owner we can see on a portrait right here. Melchior joined the Imperial Army at a young age and soon became renowned for his successful battles, particularly with the Turks in Hungary. The hardships of war took a toll on his overall health and he died in the year 1600, aged just 45, of an illness while travelling to yet another battlefield. His body was returned home and laid to rest in a family tomb. Opposite his portrait we can take a look at some of the remains, which were raised from the tomb at the beginning of the last century. A humerus (arm bone), a rapier and a helmet are placed together in the showcase and above it we can also see framed fragments of Melchior’s burial robe.

At the very top, there are another two emblems. The one on the right belongs to the Redern family and the second directs our attention to Melchior’s wife, Kateřina (Catharina) von Schlick. She had been administering the estates in times of her husband’s absence – which effectively means permanently – and even after his death, until their only son reached adult age. Even though she was rather unpopular among her subjects, she was also skilled, quite experienced and exceptionally well-educated, allowing her to carry out such projects as the construction of Frýdlant chateau and its chapel, as well as the family tomb in the nearby parish church.

A picture of the marble tomb hangs next to the door. The unfortunate truth is, that despite it being designed as a family tomb, Melchior ended up being the only one buried in it. Kateřina died in 1617 in Liberec, but the location of her final resting place has been a mystery for the past few centuries. Their only son Kryštof (Christoph) von Redern, being Lutheran, joined the Bohemian Revolt in 1618 and after the defeat at the Battle of White Mountain he fled to Silesia to escape the Old Town Square execution. Frýdlant was seized by the emperor and we’ll talk about its ensuing history in the following room.

rooms.title: Albrecht of Waldstein
rooms.card_label: Frýdlant was confiscated based on Redern’s Protestant affiliation in 1620, along with many other estates throughout Bohemia.
rooms.text:
Frýdlant was confiscated based on Redern’s Protestant affiliation in 1620, along with many other estates throughout Bohemia. A year later it was conveniently acquired by its most famous owner, Albrecht von Waldstein, one of the wealthiest and most powerful men in Europe of his time. Despite him never staying at Frýdlant and only visiting it three times, Waldstein’s name became closely tied to the region. The main reason for that is Albrecht being the only duke of Frýdlant, as he was able to obtain several adjacent domains and create his personal duchy. While under the duke’s administration, the region earned its byname: “Terra Felix”. That’s latin for “Fortunate Land”. The nickname was well deserved, as Frýdlant happened to be one of the few areas in Europe standing aside the raging Thirty Years' War, thanks to Waldstein’s remarkable strategies.

However, the duke has not acquired his unparalleled wealth and social standing solely through his skills and diligence, but also via a series of schemes and machinations. His ambition and slyness had made him unreliable for the emperor’s court and when Waldstein’s own generals expressed their concerns about a possible conspiracy with the Swedes, the emperor gave the order to either arrest Albrecht von Waldstein or have him killed. Thus it came to pass, that Waldstein was murdered in the February of 1634 in Cheb, western Bohemia. A scene of his assassination is hanging by the window and on the opposite side we can also see his last 3 loyal officers being murdered too that very evening. Although the painting of the duke’s death is quite narrative and accompanied by a list of all depicted figures, it’s also slightly misleading – at the time of his murder Waldstein had been severely ill for some time and dying of syphilis, which would prevent him from springing out of his bed.

Let’s look at the two generals who betrayed Waldstein, Matthias von Gallas and Ottavio Piccolomini. As a reward for their loyalty to the emperor they were given a large part of the duke’s property. Gallas became the owner of Frýdlant, Liberec and Smiřice. The following hall is dedicated to him and his descendants.

rooms.title: Knight's hall
rooms.card_label: Even though Matthias von Gallas gained the ownership of Frýdlant, he didn’t really get to enjoy it.
rooms.text:
Even though Matthias von Gallas gained the ownership of Frýdlant, he didn’t really get to enjoy it. Shortly after Waldstein’s demise, the Swedish army conquered the whole region and alternately occupied Frýdlant for over 15 years until the Peace of Westphalia.

Gallas perished about a year before the war ended, therefore when Swedes left Frýdlant for good in 1649, the domain passed into ownership of his two sons, Anton Pancratius and Franz Ferdinand von Gallas, both of which were adolescent and the property was managed by their guardians.

After multiple partitions and redistributions of family estates, Frýdlant and Liberec became property of the elder brother, Franz Ferdinand. This well educated noble man enjoyed travelling and during his grand tour through Western Europe he became quite fond of contemporaneous architectural style, which we now know as baroque. This interest is reflected in his portrait, where we can spot an architectural plan in the count’s right hand. Not only has he redesigned the interiors of Frýdlant castle in a fashionable way, he also founded the nearby pilgrimage church and monastery in Hejnice and built a new tomb of the Gallas (and later Clam-Gallas) family there. By his side we find Johanna Emerentia Gaschin von Rosenberg, his wife. This couple had ten children, which was not unusual in the time. Unfortunately, child mortality in the early 17th century ranged between 40 to 50 %. Emerentia passed at the respectable age of 92 years, meaning she outlived not only all of her children, but also several of her grand-children.

Their eldest son and presumptive heir fell victim to an illness at the age of 20, whilst on his own grand tour. Just six days later their second-born son was killed by the Turks on a Balkan battlefield. Fortunately, the third-born child, Johan Weneslaw, lived long enough to inherit the title and affiliated wealth. Unlike his ancestors, he chose a path of diplomacy rather than military and spent a great part of his life abroad. The count held the post of ambassador to London, Haag and Rome and at the peak of his career (in 1719) he was appointed viceroy of Naples. The journey to Naples turned out to be fatal for Johan – travelling in an open carriage during July heat, he contracted fever and died just three weeks later. He was laid to rest in one of Neapolitan churches, but his heart was buried in Hejnice monastery, among his family.

Visavis Johan Wenceslaw we see his wife Anna Maria von Dietrichstein. She was praised as one of the prettiest women at the imperial court, but suffered from poor health and passed away at the age of 23, only a few months after giving birth to their only son and heir Phillip Joseph von Gallas. Philip followed in his father's footsteps and had a fine political career, serving as the High Judge of the Royal Court and the High Steward of the Bohemian kingdom. A childless marriage with his first cousin, Anna Maria Colonna von Fels led to the necessity of finding a suitable beneficiary. The final choice fell upon their nephew under the condition of compounding both family names. Hence a whole new lineage came into existence.

The first member of Clam-Gallas family would be the aforementioned nephew, Christian Phillip Clam-Gallas. He was a generous benefactor of art and culture in general. His founding activities included nearby Libverda Spa, popular Klamovka Gardens in Prague and much more, but let’s save that for the following chamber.

rooms.title: Dining hall
rooms.card_label: The smaller of two paintings on the left side of the window portrays Christian Phillip and on the opposite side we can see a matching frame with a likeness of his wife, Caroline Josephine Sporck.
rooms.text:
The smaller of two paintings on the left side of the window portrays Christian Phillip and on the opposite side we can see a matching frame with a likeness of his wife, Caroline Josephine Sporck. Caroline shared her husband’s passion for art and was a keen collector. Thanks to her, Frýdlant picture galleries include works of such authors as Škréta, Reinar or Brandl.

As we noted earlier, Christian Phillip founded a spa in Libverda. Such facilities were very popular among nobility of the 18th and 19th century and gained a great social significance.Libverda became a favourite destination of noble guests and the demand for cultural events and entertainment kept rising. Musical or theatrical performances were held mainly in evenings and seemed insufficient, therefore the Clam-Gallas family decided to open up their own estate. The first exhibitions were opened for visitors in the summer of 1801 and Frýdlant is recognised as the eldest castle museum in Central Europe. Such novelty made the spa more attractive for distinguished clientele and it’s also worth mentioning that a well-received trilogy called Wallenstein was published around the same time and the connection to a popular historical figure drew even more attention to Frýdlant and Libverda.

Initially, the museum consisted of four rooms filled with portraits of family ancestors and previous owners of Frýdlant. Soon after opening, the exhibition was accompanied by growing collections of arts, weapons, souvenirs and other artifacts. Credit for that goes to Christian Phillip’s son, Christian Chrisoph. In addition to his charitable sponsorship and founding of many welfare institutions, he inherited his parents’ appreciation of culture too and not only bestowed his patronage on renowned artists, but also co-founded The Society of Patriotic Friends of Fine Arts, which led to the foundation of The Academy of Fine Arts and The National Gallery. Christoph himself had an artistic talent (some of his works are still on display in The National Gallery in Prague) and was particularly keen on theatre. His wife Josephine von Clary-Aldringen was, for a change, a gifted soprano and played numerous instruments. She took piano lessons from Ludwig van Beethoven, who also dedicated a few of his compositions to her and they performed several concerts together.

Christoph and Josephine welcomed five offspring – 3 daughters and 2 sons. Older of the two boys, Wilhelm was to become an heir, but he died of typhus shortly after celebrating his 20th birthday and the title unexpectedly fell to his younger brother Eduard.

Eduard Clam-Gallas aimed for a military career and at the age of 18 he joined the cavalry. He achieved remarkable successes during campaigns in northern Italy, after which he was assigned command of the Army Corps of Bohemia and appointed general of the cavalry. He was decorated with the Military Order of Maria Theresa, received the knighthood of the Order of the Golden Fleece of Austria and he earned many other honours. His brilliant career came to an abrupt end in the Austro-Prussian War. Eduard made mistakes which led to the infamous defeat and eventually brought him to military court. Although he was of course acquitted of all charges, the trial itself was such a humiliation for the general, that he secluded himself and never joined the military again. He devoted the rest of his life to management of his family estates along with his wife Clothilde von Dietrichstein. Because they wished to use Frýdlant as their main residence, they finished the construction of the new chateau wing and renovated the older chateau one (which was up until then used as an administrative building). After those readjustments, the castle could be completely filled with museum expositions.

Speaking of Eduard’s wife Clothilde, whose photo we’ll see later on our tour, it’s important to mention that she herself was quite an active and, in context of her era, empowered woman. She was a palace lady (lady in waiting) to the Austrian empress Elisabeth Bavarian, a member of the Order of the Starry Cross and an honorary lady of the Knights Hospitaller. After her father's death she inherited considerable assets and independently managed several estates, some of which she later gifted to her granddaughters. She gave birth tothree daughters (note: third of them died just a few days old and Clothilde tragically aborted at least two following pregnancies) and an only son.

Franz, the last male holder of Clam-Gallas name and title, took interest in numerous fields. He was a sportsman, traveler, keen automobilist and a polyglot. He studied law and history at university in Vienna and attended lectures on agriculture and forestry. His fondness of Jizera mountains’ woods was apparent all through his life, while forestry has as well been the main source of income for C-G family. During his studies he met countess Maria, who soon became his wife. They started a family here in Northern Bohemia, and whilst trying to produce a male heir they had no less than seven daughters. In 1918, to both luck and misfortune of the Clam-Gallas family, the Habsburg Empire fell apart and Czechoslovakia was formed. The young, progressive and democratic country’s law provided equal rights for women and removed other obstacles to splitting the property among Franz’s daughters, bringing him great relief. However, new and possibly even greater worries ensued due to the land reform – the former count’s cherished forest land was gradually confiscated and the financial compensation was far from adequate. This radical intervention resulted in the loss of the family's main income, leading to a major redundancy and constraint of Franz’s ability to fund various associations and institutions. He tirelessly attempted to reason with authorities, to substitute seized forests with agricultural land, he sold off the Liberec castle and provided the Prague palace for use to one of the new government's ministries, but all to no avail. On Christmas holiday of 1929 he received news of the final extent of the reform. The Clam-Gallas family was to lose about two thirds of their forests. It was the last blow for 75 year old Franz. He suffered a cardiac event leading to his passing three weeks later.

C-G estate, or what was left of it, was subsequently distributed in between his daughters. Frýdlant was left to the second youngest, Clothilde. At that time, she was the only unmarried of the seven sisters and the last one to reside here and help with managing the property. Clothilde continued living here and taking care of her widowed mother until her demise eight years later. After Maria’s death and with growing Nazzi enthusiasm among inhabitants of Frýdlant city, Clothilde decided to temporarily move to Vienna, where she felt safer and less observable. Her idea of returning home as soon as the situation calms down turned into waiting for the end of the war and finally completely fell apart with post-war settlements. In 1945 the Beneš decrees were introduced, creating legal ground for appropriating estates of all Germans, unless they should be able to prove their active participation in anti-nazzi resistance. Clothilde and her sisters decided to declare their nationality as German (Austrian) in the last population and housing census in 1929, therefore after WW2 all of the Clam-Gallas estates were seized. Clothilde had to keep living in Austria, where she died in 1975 as the last bearer of her family’s name.

Ever since then, Frýdlant has been state owned. Thanks to the long history of its museum, the castle was opened to the public again very shortly after the confiscation, with new additions to tour routes – family’s private chambers. After the successful communist coup in 1948, all remaining private castles and palaces in Czechoslovakia were stolen from their owners. Those houses, which were destined for tourism, went through a scheme of redistribution of furnishings and works of art, and during this process, almost 40 % of the valuables were misappropriated. Frýdlant avoided this only by already having every smallest thing listed in official state issued inventory. Many other mansions weren’t so lucky and suffered the grim fate of being repurposed for army, agriculture and other unsuitable use. Inpresent date, our castle and chateau stands out in the context of Czech cultural heritage, as one of the few authentically furnished noble residences.

Now let’s enjoy the rest of our tour, where we’ll focus less on history and more on what's around us to see.

rooms.title: Sporck gallery
rooms.card_label: Do you recall Caroline Josephine Sporck? She was married to the first count Clam-Gallas and a keen arts lover.
rooms.text: Do you recall Caroline Josephine Sporck? She was married to the first count Clam-Gallas and a keen arts lover. You probably remember that she expanded Frýdlant collections with paintings by famous baroque painters – Škréta, Reinar, Brandl… Some of them were newly bought, some were a part of her dowry, including the most prized canvas in our castle. It hangs right in front of you, in the frame with number 5 on the top. The portrait depicts her grand uncle Anton Sporck (Antonín Špork), the founder of baths in Kuks, and was painted by Peter Brandl. Surrounding paintings portray other Sporck family members.

rooms.title: Graphics parlour
rooms.card_label: Let’s circle back in time, to the 18th century, when the castle fort was still inhabited and the chateau was used mostly for administrative matters.
rooms.text:
Let’s circle back in time, to the 18th century, when the castle fort was still inhabited and the chateau was used mostly for administrative matters. Frýdlant was obviously frequently visited by a variety of guests, of which the most important was undoubtedly the emperor Joseph II., who spent a night here amid his inspection tour of Bohemia.

Friends and relatives of count’s family used to come more often indeed. Such visits usually stretched over a longer time than we are used to in modern times, to make it worth the lengthy journeys. Because of that, it was necessary to provide your guests with comfort, sometimes for as long as several weeks. Guest quarters are adaptable, it was common to convert other rooms to bedchambers to welcome the desired number of guests. More rooms were used to accommodate all usual needs of a noble company – maybe you’ve noticed we walked through a banquet hall, where we talked about the latest history, and now we are standing in a parlour.

The function of a parlour or a drawing room is similar to modern day living rooms. It’s a place for resting or having fun, alone or in company. Guests passed their time by reading, talking, enjoying music or playing various games. A billiard table, which used to be here, is sadly missing, as well as a portion from the collection of graphics. The largest of them stayed in its place, an impressive copperplate shows us the 18th century’s Rome.

We talked about how the owners added bedchambers for their guests if needed, but today we’ll see only one. You may walk right in.

rooms.title: Bedchamber
rooms.card_label: Baroque style furnishing dates the bedchamber to the late 18th century, although it presumably served its purpose even 100 years later, if the guests wished to enjoy their stay at Frýdlant in the romantic “medieval” castle.
rooms.text:
Baroque style furnishing dates the bedchamber to the late 18th century, although it presumably served its purpose even 100 years later, if the guests wished to enjoy their stay at Frýdlant in the romantic “medieval” castle.

Now let’s continue through the hunting themed passage to a room of military memorabilia.

rooms.title: Hunting themed anteroom
rooms.card_label: Notice the year captioned on this shooting target. It refers to the first opening of our museum in 1801.
rooms.text:
Notice the year captioned on this shooting target. It refers to the first opening of our museum in 1801.

Hunting used to be a popular sport and the forests and mountains surrounding Frýdlant were most suitable for it. Furthermore, Eduard Clam-Gallas created an enclosure (game park) with an area of 55 km2, in its time the second largest in Bohemia. A fence made of stone blocks and wooden planks was erected all around its 42 km perimeter, sometimes in hardly accessible terrain. Remains of it can still be seen today in Jizera mountains, for instance near Oldřichov or Bedřichov, where you can find long rows of two-ton granite blocks.

Renowned hunts and chases at Frýdlant were attended by Austrian and Bohemian elite. We can see some of their names on all the game trophies, usually accompanied by date and location of the hunting success.

Eduard’s son Franz was in frequent attendance too. Nevertheless, later in life he found interest in tourism and hiking, which led him to shutting down major hunting areas and building new hiking paths.

rooms.title: Cabinet of the general
rooms.card_label: We entered a so-called cabinet, a display room presenting various reminders of Eduard’s military career.
rooms.text:
We entered a so-called cabinet, a display room presenting various reminders of Eduard’s military career. Showcases are filled with his numerous decorations. We may have a look at the insignia of the Order of the Golden Fleece, that’s the one suspended from a red ribbon, or the insignia of the Order of the Iron Crown – a plaque and blue-yellow sash.

In addition to Eduard’s own uniforms (of Hussar, Dragoon and Uhlan regiments), the collection includes an uniform of his colleague and a great friend, field marshal Radetzky, who gifted it himself to be displayed in the growing castle museum.

rooms.title: Corridor with tiles
rooms.card_label: Taxidermied anomalies are a remnant of past approach to creating exhibitions.
rooms.text:
Taxidermied anomalies are a remnant of past approach to creating exhibitions. Anything rare, uncommon or bizarre was generally desired.

Across the narrow corridor there are two baroque-era sledges, one of them should resemble a dolphin.

If you raise your eyes to the ceiling, you can take a glimpse at the renaissance-era painted ceiling.

This intriguing array is completed with a display of hand painted 17th century tiles, predominantly of Dutch provenience.

rooms.title: Servant dining room
rooms.card_label: This room, labeled as a servants dining room in historical guidebooks, is once again furnished in baroque style.
rooms.text:
This room, labeled as a servants dining room in historical guidebooks, is once again furnished in baroque style. That corresponds with the sizable masonry stove and the set of pewter tableware. Pewter ware used to be the prevalent kind of tableware in well situated households, until porcelain took its place around the eighteen hundreds. You may have noticed the absence of cutlery. Not that it wasn’t used, but in the 17th century, plenty of dishes were still commonly consumed with fingers. You can thusely imagine how convenient it was to be able to wash your hands in between different courses without leaving the table and that’s the exact purpose of this portable wash basin, also called lavabo.

If you’re not afraid of heights, please come take a look around from our balcony.

rooms.title: Under the tower
rooms.card_label: As you might have already guessed from the curvature of this wall, we’re passing the main tower Indika.
rooms.text:
As you might have already guessed from the curvature of this wall, we’re passing the main tower Indika. It reaches a height of 49 m, with a diameter of about 10 m. The walls at this level are still approximately 4 m thick, not leaving much space inside the tower itself, therefore there’s no staircase in the lower half. Instead, there are two rooms – one here, one on the next floor. In the distant past, when Indika was standing on this hill all alone, these rooms could be solely accessed by ladder. In case of a siege, the ladder would be pulled up and the crew hid safely inside. Similarly, after the eldest castle palaces had been erected, the watchtower was connected to them by a drawbridge and still served as the last stronghold, should the castle be invaded. This type of tower is called “belfry” (“bergfried” in German). When the castle further developed, it absorbed the tower and its rooms were given a new purpose – this one became a prison and the other one a treasure room. Both were used up until the mid 17th century and have been empty ever since.

We will climb the stairs now and above them, you may take a look at the upper room, which is kept open, and see with your own eyes how thick the walls are.

rooms.title: Armory
rooms.card_label: The renaissance-era painted ceiling with the Rederns family coat of arms reveals former representative use.
rooms.text:
The renaissance-era painted ceiling with the Rederns family coat of arms reveals former representative use. However, for the past two hundred years at least, an armoury has been on display here. We can see a large collection of muskets, halberds and other weaponry, mostly from the Thirty Years' War era or slightly younger. Few older specimens worth mentioning are among them. For instance arquebuses. Their name comes from the Dutch word “haakbus” which translates to “hook gun”. This rather primitive type of handguns is typical for the early 15th century. It’s very heavy and needed to be steadied against a battlement or other structure because of its mighty recoil. Other weapons of the same period can be seen at the opposite wall. That’s Hussite weaponry, forged from farming tools.

In the other room, there’s a couple of small scale cannons and also mortars.

rooms.title: Horse harnesses
rooms.card_label: Here we have, side by side, two kinds of festive harnesses.
rooms.text:
Here we have, side by side, two kinds of festive harnesses. Collar harnesses are decorated with silver and breast strap harnesses decorated with gold. Both were used for drawing carriages.

Proportions of this carriage chassis indicates that it was not drawn by horses. Small scaled carriages like this one were meant for children and would be most likely drawn by a pony. Or even goats, as we can see on a photograph of Franz’s daughters, who had a similar phaeton..

Another curiosity is the messenger’s equipment. This is not a hat, although it might look like one. It’s a fashionable crossbody satchel, with a single compartment for carrying letters. And these considerably large boots are also meant for long distance horse-back travelling. They were worn over casual boots and stuffed with hay to keep the rider’s feet warm and dry.

rooms.title: Castle gallery
rooms.card_label: A castle museum would not be whole without a gallery.
rooms.text:
A castle museum would not be whole without a gallery. Here we can see portraits of various monarchs from all across Europe, including several emperors as well as Spanish infanta Margarita. Alongside them are depictions of ladies in waiting, portraits of other significant personas and artistic pieces. Next to the masonry heater hangs a trio of English genre paintings, in between the windows is a likeness of Bernard Ingaz von Martinitz, painted by famous baroque painter Karel Škréta.

In addition to the canvases, we can also admire servants’ uniforms. Most of them are festive uniforms from the late 19th century. They were worn by footmans, valets and higher rank clerks. In the shadowy corner are two liveries from the 17th century and a ladies dress.

rooms.title: Gallery with pipes
rooms.card_label: We find ourselves in the third and last castle gallery.
rooms.text:
We find ourselves in the third and last castle gallery. Landscapes around us were painted by another bohemian painter, Václav Vavřinec (Wenzel Lorenz) Reiner. This noticeably earlier piece is a 16th century picture of saint Luis, supposedly by Paolo Veronese.

Your attention was presumably caught by the display of pipes. Both Eduard and Franz Clam-Gallas were avid collectors and their laudable collection amounts to around 220 specimens of marvelous shapes, various sizes and materials, some of them even from remote parts of the world.

rooms.title: Administrator's office
rooms.card_label: The last room of our tour is a later addition to museum exhibits and is supposed to demonstrate how offices of the castle administration looked like.
rooms.text:
The last room of our tour is a later addition to museum exhibits and is supposed to demonstrate how offices of the castle administration looked like. An essential element of the offices of higher ranked clerks is a nice seating separated from the employees desks. Its purpose is simple – when the count came to discuss some agenda, his clerks were able to seat him comfortably and aside from their unfinished work.

Next to the door, you can spot a large map. It was painted in 1660 by Samuel Globitz and captures the Frýdlant region. The only city accompanied by capital F is obviously Frýdlant and above it is our castle. Surrounding towns and villages are marked with numbers and listed in the bottom left corner.

Last but not least, allow me to point out the price list on the other side from the door. It’s more than a century old and discloses admission charges to our museum. Single visitor used to pay 1 Austro-Hungarian krone (or 1 German Goldmark) and if a group of at least 5 people showed up, the price was discounted to 20 hellers (or pfennigs) per person.

When you are done inspecting the office, you may exit to the hallway and continue through the arcade and all the way down the stairs to the castle courtyard.

rooms.title: Castle courtyard
rooms.card_label: This is where our tour ends.
rooms.text: This is where our tour ends. You’ve seen about 20 chambers and passages in two and a half floor of the castle. I hope you enjoyed it and that, perhaps, you will visit us again to see our other tours as well. I’ll let you out of the gate now. Have a wonderful day.

tours.title: Die Burg
tours.description: Die Führung führt den Besucher durch die Obere Burg, den ältesten Teil des Frýdlant-Gebiets. Der gesamte Weg wird dominiert von einem großen Rittersaal mit Ahnenempore, einer Rüstkammer, einem Festsaal oder einer großen Sammlung von Dienstkleidung.

rooms.title: Der untere Schlosshof
rooms.card_label: Wir befinden uns auf dem unteren Schlosshof, woher wir das ganze Objekt überblicken können.
rooms.text:
Sehr geehrte Besucher, herzlich willkommen auf dem Staatsschloss und der Staatsburg Frýdlant. Bevor wir anfangen, bitte ich Sie, Ihre Handys stumm zu schalten, damit die Führung nicht gestört wird. Wenn Sie einen Audioguide benutzen, setzen Sie bitte Ihre Kopfhörer auf. Außerdem bitten wir Sie, die ausgestellten Exponate nicht zu berühren und immer bei Ihrer Gruppe zu bleiben. Fotografieren ist erlaubt. Wir bedanken uns bei Ihnen für Ihr Verständnis und wünschen Ihnen einen angenehmen Besuch.

 Wir befinden uns auf dem unteren Schlosshof, von wo aus Sie das ganze Objekt überblicken können. Rechts, am Eingang, gibt es ursprüngliche Burgmauern. Als Sie hierher gegangen sind, mussten sie an einem steilen Weg vorbei gehen. Dieser Weg wird „Ritterweg“ genannt, weil hier damals Ritter auf Pferden bis hinauf in die Burg geritten sind. Die Damen wiederum wurden in ihren Sänften getragen. Aber heutzutage müssen leider alle zu Fuß gehen. Die Sänften sehen Sie dann später in der Burg.

 Noch höher, hinter den Bäumen, steht die Burg. Sie gehört zu den ältesten und mächtigsten Burgen in Nordböhmen. Die Burg wurde im 13. Jahrhundert im gotischen Baustil erbaut. Neben ihr gibt es die Schlosskapelle - das kleine, gelbe Gebäude. Von der Schlosskapelle kann man in das sog. Alte Schloss aus dem 16. Jahrhundert gehen. An seiner Fassade können wir noch erhaltene Renaissance Sgraffitos sehen. Und das große gelbe Gebäude ist der jüngste Teil des Objektes. Das ist das sog. Neue Schloss aus dem 19. Jahrhundert.

 Wir gehen jedoch in die Burg und haben gleich zwei Möglichkeiten. Entweder benutzen wir die Treppe oder gehen über den Ritterweg. Wir treffen uns wieder vor der Schlosskapelle.

rooms.title: Vor der Schlosskapelle
rooms.card_label: Wir befinden uns vor der Burg und der Schlosskapelle.
rooms.text:
Wir befinden uns vor der Burg und der Schlosskapelle. Die Burg steht auf einem natürlichen Basaltfelsen, der einer Sage nach vom Teufel gepflügt wurde. Darum wird er auch Teufelsorgel genannt.

Der Bogen über uns heißt Schwibbogen und diente damals als Brücke zwischen der Burg und der Kapelle. Weil die Schlosskapelle wiederum auch mit dem Schloss verbunden ist, konnte man trockenen Fußes durch alle Hauptgebäude des Areals gehen. Heute ist der Schwibbogen leider nicht mehr zugänglich. Wir gehen wenigstens unter ihm weiter bis zum oberen Burghof.

Während Sie die Treppe hinaufsteigen, sehen Sie rechts 3 alte Feuerlöscher. Bei so einem Feuerlöscher mussten gleichzeitig zwei Männer pumpen, während das Wasser durch einen Wasserschlauch gespritzt wurde. Zum Glück waren die Feuerlöscher nie im Einsatz - das bedeutet, dass hier nie ein Feuer ausbrach.

rooms.title: Der obere Burghof
rooms.card_label: Wir haben nun den oberen Burghof betreten.
rooms.text:
Wir haben nun den oberen Burghof betreten. Der Basaltfelsen ist hier ziemlich klein, deshalb beschloss man, die Burg nicht in die Breite, sondern in die Höhe zu bauen. Diese Tatsache ist zum Beispiel auf dem hohen Turm zu sehen. Er ist 49 m hoch und seine Mauern sind im ersten Stockwerk fast 4 m breit. Dort können Sie auch zwei kleine Fenster sehen, die mal ein Gefängnis, mal eine Schatzkammer waren. Der Turm wurde bereits 1014 erbaut und so ist er der älteste Teil der ganzen Burg. Oben war der Turm ursprünglich flach und oft wurde hier Feuer angezündet, so dass er als Leuchtturm auf dem Handelsweg zwischen Böhmen, der Lausitz und Polen diente. Darum wird er Indica genannt. Diesen Turm werden wir während unserer Führung zusammen besuchen.

Obwohl die Burg zunächst im gotischen Baustil erbaut wurde, wurde sie mehrmals umgebaut und heute steht hier eine Renaissanceburg aus dem 16 Jahrhundert Als Hinweis darauf gilt die ursprüngliche Fassade der Burg. Werfen Sie bitte einen Blick nach rechts, wo noch erhaltene Renaisancesgraffitos aus dem 16. Jahrhundert zu sehen sind. Die Sgraffitos wurden erst Jahrhunderte später, im Jahre 1960 während einer Rekonstruktion, entdeckt. Sie waren nämlich unter der alten Fassade versteckt. Ihre Entdeckung war für alle eine riesengroße Überraschung. Ähnliche Sgraffitos konnten Sie auch unten auf dem Alten Schloss erkennen.

Bevor wir die Burg betreten, beachten Sie noch zwei Wappen, die zwei verschiedene örtliche Adelsgeschlechter darstellen. Das kleine Wappen über dem Vordach über der Tür gehörte der Adelsfamilie von Bieberstein, die unter anderem für den Renaissanceumbau der Burg sorgte. Das zweite große Wappen an der Mauer gehörte dem Grafen Matthias aus der Adelsfamilie Gallas, der vor allem für seine Mitwirkung an der Ermordung von Albrecht von Waldstein bekannt ist. Über beide Adelsfamilien und natürlich auch über weitere Besitzer der Herrschaft Frýdlant werden Sie mehr in der Burg erfahren.

rooms.title: Der erste Burgraum
rooms.card_label: Wir befinden uns nun im ersten Burgraum und beginnen mit der ältesten Geschichte.
rooms.text:
Wir befinden uns nun im ersten Burgraum und beginnen mit der ältesten Geschichte: Der Gründer der Burg ist heute nicht mehr bekannt. Seit dem 13. Jahrhundert herrschte hier das Adelsgeschlecht von Ronow, eine der mächtigsten böhmischen Adelsfamilien. Das Baumästewappen der Familie ist über dem Eingang zu sehen.

Im Jahre 1278 wurde ihnen aber von dem böhmischen König Přemysl Otakar II. die Herrschaft genommen, um sie damit zu schwächen. Noch im selben Jahr wurde das Gut vom Adelsgeschlecht von Bieberstein gekauft. Auch ihr Geweihwappen ist in diesem Raum zu sehen. Unter ihm befinden sich Gipsabgüsse der Köpfe der Ritter dieser Familie aus ihrer Familiengruft. Außer dass Biebersteiner gegen die Hussiten kämpften, realisierten sie auch den Renaissanceumbau der alten Burg. Sie blieben am längsten hier, fast 300 Jahre. Dann hatte aber der letzte Biebesteiner keinen männlichen Nachfolger und so starb das Adelsgeschlecht von Bieberstein 1551 aus. Nach sieben Jahren wurde Frýdlant von der Adelsfamilie von Redern gekauft. Ihr Wappen ist bereits viel verzierter als die vorherigen und auch entsprechend größer. Dieser Adelsfamilie schulden wir viel – ohne sie wären hier gar kein Schloss und auch keine Schlosskapelle. Der bekannteste von ihnen war Melchior von Redern, der auf dem Gemälde in der Mitte abgebildet ist. Melchior war angeblich ein hervorragender Kämpfer. Er kämpfte zum Beispiel gegen die Türken in Ungarn. Nach seinem Tod im Jahre 1600 übernahm das Gut Frýdlant seine Frau Katharina von Redern. Ihr Bild ist zwischen den Fenstern zu sehen. Die sterblichen Überreste von Melchior sind in dieser Vitrine links von der Tür ausgestellt. Und in dem kleinen Sarg liegt sein Armknochen.

Katharina von Redern war eine sehr energische, aber auch sehr selbstsüchtige Frau, weshalb sie von der Bevölkerung den Spitznamen 'böse Katharina' erhielt. Sie ließ die Schlosskapelle, das Alte Schloss und die Familiengruft in der Kirche von Frýdlant bauen und schaffte es auch sogar, fast alle alten Schulden der Melchiors abzuzahlen. Auf der anderen Seite stritt sie sich lange mit den Bürgern um das Braurecht und als sie diesen Streit verlor, ließ sie den Bürgern zum Trotz das sog. 'Trotz-Haus' hier auf dem Marktplatz in Frýdlant errichten, um die Bürger damit ärgern zu können. Es steht bis heute dort. Weil sie so unbeliebt war, sorgten ihre Untertanen nach ihrem Tod 1618 dafür, dass ihre Leiche nie gefunden wurde.

Als Katharina starb, übernahm ihr Sohn Christoph von Redern die Verwaltung der Herrschaft. Der ist auf dem Bild rechts mit einem Schwert in der Hand zu sehen. Weil er protestantisch war, kämpfte er im Dreißigjährigen Krieg gegen den Kaiser. Im Jahre 1620 nahm er zusammen mit seinem Onkel an der Schlacht auf dem Weißen Berg teil. Als der Widerstand geschlagen wurde, musste Christoph fliehen, um nicht hingerichtet zu werden. Sein Onkel schaffte das jedoch nicht und wurde am 21. Juni 1621 auf dem Altstädterring in Prag mit noch 26 anderen Herren hingerichtet.

Seit 1620 war das Gut Frýdlant ohne Besitzer, blieb so aber nicht lange. Bald nutzte nämlich der bekannteste Besitzer Albrecht von Waldstein diese seltene Möglichkeit aus und kaufte das Gut zu einem günstigen Preis. Über ihn werden wir in dem nächsten Raum sprechen.

rooms.title: Albrecht von Wallenstein
rooms.card_label: Als die Adelsfamilie von Redern ihre Herrschaft verlassen musste, wurde Frýdlant 1622 von Albrecht von Waldstein, Herzog von Frýdlant, übernommen.
rooms.text:
Als die Adelsfamilie von Redern ihre Herrschaft verlassen musste, wurde Frýdlant 1622 von Albrecht von Waldstein, Herzog von Frýdlant, übernommen. Seine Herrschaft hatte zwar keine Auswirkungn auf die Burggestalt – er lieβ keine neuen Gebäude bauen, aber es gab eine große wirtschaftliche Entwicklung.
